Award.AwardTitle: Long-term Perspectives on Human-River Dynamics at the Confluence of the Illinois and Mississippi Rivers: Interdisciplinary Research for Students in Ecology and Archeology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supported under the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program, which is an NSF-wide program although each Directorate administers its own REU Site competition. This program supports active research participation by undergraduate students in an effort to introduce them to scientific research so as to encourage their continued engagement in the nation's scientific research and development enterprise. REU projects involve students in meaningful ways in ongoing research programs or in research projects designed especially for the purpose. The REU program is a major contributor to the NSF's goal of developing a diverse, internationally competitive, and globally-engaged science and engineering workforce. The Social, Behavioral and Economic (SBE) sciences Directorate awarded this REU Site grant to the Center for American Archaeology with the goal of developing critical thinking proficiency, STEM skills, and scientific literacy that are necessary for undergraduate students to have successful careers in science and/or to make informed contributions to public dialogues about science. This REU Site provides instruction and practical experiences in 1) scientific problem-solving and hypothesis-testing; 2) research design and implementation; 3) data collection and analysis; 4) interpretation of results; and 5) professional and public communication of scientific knowledge within the context of a collaborative, multi-year interdisciplinary archeological/ecological project in which each student is involved for one year. The scientific process is best taught through immersive research experiences: thus, this REU site trains future scientists and scientifically savvy citizens in essential collaboration skills and the ways in which today's problems are informed through interdisciplinary research.

This REU site, with a unique interdisciplinary focus on anthropological and ecological sciences, immerses undergraduate students in problem-oriented research and allows students to confront challenges inherit to both fields while teaching them to be critical evaluators of scientific information and preparing them for careers in the sciences. The aforementioned competencies are gained through participation in collaborative interdisciplinary archeological and ecological research investigating deep-time human-ecosystem interactions at the confluence of the Mississippi and Illinois rivers. Integrating deep-time perspectives within current regional ecological models is keenly important as humans escalate modifications of riverine ecosystems. Human engagement with riverine systems and associated environments extends over millennia, yet our measurement of human impacts encompasses at most the late 19th century to the present. This leaves a markedly foreshortened perspective against which to measure effects of industrial farming, urban development, climate change, invasive species introductions, and other anthropogenic factors, on riverine ecosystems. Ecological science in general, as well as our understanding of river ecosystems, is characterized by an underdeveloped appreciation for the long-term presence of humans in this rich riverine landscape. The program is open to all college students, while targeting community college students and others with little experience or access to research opportunities. Recruitment is facilitated through institutional ties with Lewis & Clark Community College as the lead institution in a nine community college consortium located in eight states along the Mississippi River region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project Long-term Perspectives on Human-River Dynamics at the Confluence of the Illinois and Mississippi Rivers: Interdisciplinary Research for Students in Ecology and Archeology, funded by the National Science Foundation’s Research Experiences for Undergraduates program, is a participatory research program for undergraduates designed to teach STEM skills, critical thinking, and scientific literacy through immersion in interdisciplinary research on human-environment interactions as monitored by archaeological, anthropological, and ecological approaches using datasets from the Mississippi-Illinois Rivers Confluence region. These goals were accomplished through three eight-week programs of intensive research experiences in archaeology, geophysical prospection, zooarchaeology, ecology, paleoethnobotany, and ethnography at the Center for American Archeology (CAA) in Kampsville, IL.  


During the course of the program, 27 undergraduates from around the country, primarily from colleges and universities without research opportunities for undergraduates, participated in original research at the CAA.  In Year 1 (2015) students focused on human-riverine resources, particularly fish exploitation from several pre-Columbian archaeological sites in the confluence region. This portion of the program combined archaeological and ecological approaches to research problems. Students participating in Years 2-3 (2018-19) focused on pre-Columbian, historic, and modern human-plant interactions, particularly regarding the domestication of local plants, maize (corn), and modern domesticates. Students in Years 2 and 3 engaged in archaeology, paleoethnobotany, and ethnography research.  By participating in this program, students in all years learned how to conduct collaborative scientific research, from the development of initial research question(s) and research design, to data collection, analysis, and presentation to public, stakeholder, and professional audiences. This was accomplished through student participation in ongoing research at the CAA, for example, participating in archaeological fieldwork at archaeological sites and through development of original research projects on program topics. Student research projects were presented to local audiences and at professional conferences. By engaging in multiple research experiences, students successfully learned about the academic research process, developing their own research skills and increasing their scientific literacy through multidisciplinary research. Public engagement with students in the program allowed them the opportunity to share research with community members and helped raise awareness of scientific research and its potential amongst the public. REU students at the CAA exited the program with new STEM skills and research experiences that will guide their future professional development and with improved scientific literacy necessary to critically engage issues concerning science and society as informed citizens.


In addition to fostering science careers and literacy, REU program students contributed to the creation of new knowledge through their participation in CAA projects and their own original research projects. All students participated in archaeological fieldwork, lab work, and geophysical survey (magnetometry, ground-penetrating radar, electrical resistance) at sites in the Lower Illinois Valley. Student fieldwork contributed new knowledge of the Golden Eagle site, Kampsville Lock site, and the German site. At the Golden Eagle site (ca 50 BCE-1000 CE), they participated in the documentation of the only known mound-and-embankment site in the confluence area. At the Kampsville Lock site, they conducted geophysical survey (remote sensing) of one of the earliest lock and dam sites in the Lower Illinois Valley—an important part of both local history and the history of river domestication in the midcontinent. At the German site, they documented pre-Columbian residential site (ca 800-1200 CE), including storage pits, earth ovens, and a house basin. Individual research projects covered a wide range topics relevant to program themes, including fish diversity, abundance, and size at pre-Columbian sites, plant usage, cooking methods, stone tools manufacture and usage, site organization, cultural landscapes, agriculture and identity, and prairie restoration. Student posters may be found on the CAA’s website: 

 

  • Year 1 (2015): https://www.caa-archeology.org/human-riverine-interactions-at-mississippi-illinois-river-confluence-reu-student-posters-2015/
  • Year 2 (2018): https://www.caa-archeology.org/food-production-past-and-present-multidisciplinary-perspectives/
  • Year 3 (2019): https://www.caa-archeology.org/living-landscapes-growing-communities-and-crops-in-the-lower-illinois-river-valley/
